title-group.article-title: The New Pension Scheme in Britain

p.mixed-citation: See Cmnd 9691, Appendix, Table 1. If real earnings growth is 1 per cent per annum, the contribution rate rises by about 3 percentage points. The impact of an unemployment rate change is described in the text. Indexing the basic pension to earnings raises the contribution rate by 5 percentage points.

See The Observer, 18 October 1987. Apart from the maximum sum which can be taken tax-free, from March 1987 new entrants to occupational schemes are limited in their pension benefits to a certain fixed multiple of final year salary.
See 'Time to plan pensions', The Observer, 29 November 1987.
But see, for example, Blundell et al. (1986).

Calculations by the Government Actuary suggest, however, that the degree of contracting-out makes little difference to National Insurance contribution rates in the long run. By 2033/34, the contribution rate will only be 0.2 per cent lower if additional numbers contracted-out rise from 500,000 to 5 million. This is because the contracted-out rebate will have fallen significantly by that time.

In general, there are pitfalls in estimating substitution effects using data on contributions to private pension schemes derived from studies of household expenditure, particularly where not all occupational schemes are contributory or fully funded. See Hemming and Harvey (1983).
Not surprisingly, Green, Hadjimatheou and Smail (1985) find that entitlement to a private pension among individuals depends on occupational group and positively on length of job tenure.
